awd_titl_txt: Dynamic fragmentation and inelastic energy partitioning at the base of the seismogenic zone
awd_abstract_narration:
Strike-slip faults like the San Andreas Fault in California represent major threats to life and property owing to the repeated generation of large earthquakes. Less than 20% of the total energy released during an earthquake radiates away from the source as seismic waves that cause ground shaking. Thus, a large portion of the energy is dissipated around the fault as frictional heat and by a variety of processes that lead to rock damage. During each earthquake, the rocks surrounding the ruptured segment of the fault are fragmented by cracking of individual mineral grains. Over many earthquake cycles, these rocks become so damaged that their elastic properties change, and this causes changes in the speed and preferred propagation direction of seismic waves. These so-called damage zones are therefore of great importance for understanding seismic hazards. Despite their importance, there is almost no direct information on the vertical extent of damage zones within active faults like the San Andreas, but this information is critical for our understanding of the energy budget through the entire seismogenic zone. The combination of modeling and field-based results from this work will allow improved characterization of seismically active faults in the deeper reaches of the seismogenic zone, including conceptual and wave speed models that can be used to better predict ground shaking directions and intensities. The open-source codes and analytical protocols developed in this project will be made available through existing public portals, and will have many community applications including the relationships between microcrack orientation and state of stress, interpretation of seismological data, and analysis of brittle damage and fragmentation of ceramics and advanced composite materials. Additional desired societal outcomes include full participation of women in STEM and development of a globally competitive STEM workforce through graduate and undergraduate student training.

The objectives of this project are to: (1) comprehensively characterize the microfracture density and fragment size distributions for garnet and feldspar grains along three transects across a seismogenic fault/shear zone exhumed from near the base of the seismogenic zone (the Norumbega fault system, Maine), (2) apply physics-based fragmentation modeling to estimate fracture energies associated with the garnet fragmentation, (3) determine whether fragment size distribution analysis can be used to indicate that an exhumed fault or shear zone had a seismogenic history, (4) pursue the implications of the results for inelastic energy partitioning in the seismic source, (5) document asymmetrical damage around the shear zone core and quantitatively characterize the elastic and seismic properties of the rocks to characterize the bi-material effect, and (6) develop and disseminate protocols for using electron backscatter diffraction techniques to analyze mineral and rock fragmentation. Addressing the above objectives provides an opportunity to test hypotheses related to the source energy budget, styles of rupture propagation, and the relations between loading conditions and resulting rock microstructures in the deeper seismogenic zone. The research team will also assess whether intense fragmentation of brittle minerals can be used as a seismogenic signature at depth, as it is at the surface. Recognition of the importance of microfracturing for macroscopic behavior and the ability to treat it quantitatively is growing in both Earth sciences and materials engineering. The results of this project will provide a framework for future efforts in both fields, and for collaborations between them.

por.por_cntn:
Less than 20% of the total energy released during an earthquake radiates away from the source (the region around the propagating rupture) as elastic waves that cause ground shaking. Thus, more than 80% of the total co-seismic energy released during an earthquake is partitioned into the source region as frictional heat, and a variety of inelastic processes such as fracturing. The inelastic energy budget in the source region is of first order importance in earthquake science and hazards assessment, directly affecting patterns of slip and rupture propagation, and therefore earthquake intensity. A record of inelastic energy partitioning is well preserved around upper-crustal strike-slip faults (for example the San Andreas fault, California, USA) in the form of highly fragmented and pulverized rock. In contrast, we have very little information about how inelastic energy is partitioned at depth in the seismogenic zone.

In this project we documented, for the first time, an extensive (~70 m-wide) brittle fragmentation zone adjacent to the core of an ancient, seismogenic, strike-slip fault segment exhumed from a depth of approximately 15 kilometers. This ancient fault segment is part of the larger Norumbega fault system in Maine, USA. Fragment size distribution analyses of fragmented garnet grains indicate dynamic (co-seismic) fragmentation, which allowed us to quantitatively evaluate the integrated fracture energy generated at depth in these rocks during rupture. Our energy calculations employed techniques developed in the physics and materials science disciplines and represent a novel application to the earthquake environment. Our results suggest that fracturing and fragmentation may play a larger role as energy sinks in the source region than previously recognized.

The record of brittle damage is asymmetrically developed around the fault core (it is much wider on one side than the other), a common observation around large-displacement strike-slip faults that juxtapose rocks with significantly different elastic and seismic properties. We were able to determine the elastic and seismic properties of the rocks either side of the fault core, which allowed us to conclude that the asymmetrical damage distribution was likely caused by a preferred direction of rupture propagation over the life of the earthquake fault, which has important implications for seismic hazards assessment because seismic hazard is significantly larger in front of a propagating rupture than it is behind it.

The results of our work have advanced our understanding of inelastic energy partitioning in the source region during earthquake rupture and have global application across several geoscience and engineering disciplines. The students made original discoveries that advance our understanding within the collaborative, cross-disciplinary framework of the project. The project supported a female PhD student, campus partnerships between geosciences and mechanical engineering, and the NSF-funded scanning electron microscope laboratory in the School of Earth and Climate Sciences.

Products supported partly or entirely by this project include 9 papers published in leading peer-reviewed journals, 22 conference abstracts, 4 PhD dissertations, 2 MS theses, 1 undergraduate Honors thesis, and freely available software packages with graphical user interfaces and manuals.

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2022
Modified by: Scott E Johnson
